qas.question: What does child labour do for adults?
What happens to the wages of adults?

answers.text: depresses the wages of adults in developing countries as well as the developed countries

qas.question: What are the implications for third world countries with regards to child labour?

answers.text: low-skill jobs only capable of producing poor quality cheap exports

qas.question: Does ending child labour have a global value?

answers.text: there are moral and economic reasons that justify a blanket ban on labour

context: Some scholars[who?] suggest any labour by children aged 18 years or less is wrong since this encourages illiteracy, inhumane work and lower investment in human capital. Child labour, claim these activists, also <a0_0>leads to poor labour standards<a0_0/> for adults, <a1_0>depresses the wages of adults in developing countries as well as the developed countries<a1_0/>, and dooms the third world economies to <a2_0>low-skill jobs only capable of producing poor quality cheap exports<a2_0/>. More children that work in poor countries, the fewer and worse-paid are the jobs for adults in these countries. In other words, <a3_0>there are moral and economic reasons that justify a blanket ban on labour<a3_0/> from children aged 18 years or less, everywhere in the world.
